overview: The legislature finds that the number of registered medical cannabis patients has decreased over fifteen per cent from 35,444 card-holding patients in August 2021 to 30,035 by November 2024. [14] Amendments to the measure clarify that the state of mind requirement for the offense of operating a dispensary without a license is intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly. [15] It also specifies that a person who operates any search platform or other entity that posts information advertising the sale of cannabis products by an unlicensed person is guilty of a misdemeanor. [15]
appropriations: The appropriation for the Department of the Attorney General to enforce, and mitigate nuisances relating to, chapter 329D, HRS, shall be expended by the Attorney General. [15]
agency_impact: The measure now includes language specifying that the Department of the Attorney General's Drug Nuisance Abatement Unit may enforce nuisances relating to chapter 329D, HRS. [15] The Department of Health notes that the measure does not provide funding to support the implementation and regulation of the new cultivator license type, which will include drafting new regulations and procuring new software for licensing and tracking cultivated cannabis. [13]
economic_impact: The Hawaii State Medical Cannabis Program is in decline and requires meaningful policy that will lower the barrier to entry for patients. [13] Over the past three and a half years, the number of registered cannabis patients has declined by roughly 15%. [13] As an example of current market prices, Big Island Grown’s RSO is available at the everyday low price of $20 (HB302_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM-JDC_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) per gram. [13]
policy_impact: The state of mind requirement for the offense of operating a dispensary without a license from the Department of Health is now clarified as intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly. [15] A person who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly operates any search platform, web hosting service, or other entity that advertises the sale of cannabis products by an unlicensed person is guilty of a misdemeanor. [15] The measure also now specifies that a person issued a cannabis cultivator license is required to meet all production facility and processing requirements under chapter 329D, HRS. [15]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The measure inserts an effective date of January 1, 2027, for the requirement of cannabis cultivator licenses. [15] The Department of Health had requested a delayed effective date of July 1, 2026, to allow time to assess the bill’s impact, develop necessary regulations, and implement IT systems to support the expanded program. [13] An appropriation out of the medical cannabis registry and regulation special fund for the department of the attorney general is made for fiscal year 2025-2026 and for fiscal year 2026-2027 to enforce and mitigate nuisances relating to chapter 329D, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [14] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the attorney general for the purposes of this part. [14]
capital_expenditure_impact: The Department of Health has noted that the establishment of new cannabis cultivator licenses will require procuring new software for licensing and tracking cultivated cannabis. [13]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The measure has been amended to clarify the state of mind requirement for operating an unlicensed dispensary is intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly. [15] The penalty for operating a search platform or web hosting service that advertises the sale of cannabis by an unlicensed person has been specified as a misdemeanor. [15] The expending authority for the appropriation for nuisance enforcement has been changed from the director of health to the attorney general. [15] The bill now inserts language specifying that the Department of the Attorney General's Drug Nuisance Abatement Unit may enforce nuisances relating to chapter 329D, HRS. [15] An effective date of January 1, 2027, has been inserted for the requirement of cannabis cultivator licenses. [15]
